This a regression compared to R3.3 and should be fixed for M1.

Markus, I can create and apply a script to rename a type to F? no problem in 3.3. I can create the script in I20070808-1800 but not apply it anymore: 'The script file has invalid format'

Is in I20070808-1800:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<session version="1.0">
<refactoring comment="Rename type 'test.E01' to 'F?'
- Original project: 'P01'
- Original element: 'test.E01'
- Renamed element: 'test.F?'
- Update references to refactored element
- Update textual occurrences in comments and strings" description="Rename type 'E01'" flags="589830" id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.rename.type" input="/src<test{E01.java[E01" matchStrategy="1" name="F?" project="P01" qualified="false" references="true" similarDeclarations="false" textual="false" version="1.0"/>
</session>

Was in 3.3:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<session version="1.0">
<refactoring comment="Rename type 'test.E01' to 'F?'
- Original project: 'P01'
- Original element: 'test.E01'
- Renamed element: 'test.F?'
- Update references to refactored element
- Update textual occurrences in comments and strings" description="Rename type 'E01'" flags="589830" id="org.eclipse.jdt.ui.rename.type" input="/src<test{E01.java[E01" matchStrategy="1" name="F?" project="P01" qualified="false" references="true" similarDeclarations="false" textual="false" version="1.0"/>
</session>

I can apply the 3.3 script in I20070808-1800

This is a regression

Can you try to fix?
Got introduced by fix for bug 197722

Created an attachment (id=75741)
Patch

In the original version the Transfomer choose the encoding of the resulting file. The new DOMWriter requires a forced encoding. It currently uses the default encoding which might differ from the declared UTF-8
Patch is good, low risk fix, +1 for M1
The exception must not be catched as UTF-8 is spec'd to be always supported
Released the fix without catching the UnsupportedEncodingException.
I'm not sure this fix is correct. What happens when I use non-UTF-8 char like in my example?

There are no non-utf-8 characters ;)
UTF-8 Expands the number of bytes to express the most common charcters. Everything that can be entered in a compilation unit can be stored in UTF-8.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-8
Yep. I wasn't sure what the source is when storing the scripts. Markus confirmed that only UI strings get stored and project files aren't touched. In that case the fix works.
